note.p: This is from a series of letters written between James Finn and his fianc√©e Mary (May) Fay. They became engaged in January 1916 and married in June. They were not to be married long as in 1919 he fell ill with the great flu epidemic, it led to heart damage and he died in 1922 as she was expecting their fourth child. She held on to his letters as her reminder of him.

James Finn (1877 - 1922) was a civil servant, working in the National Health Service Commission on Mount Street. Family history says that he was advising on the restructuring of the civil service as part of setting up the new government in 1922 and that eminent figures in that project were visiting him in his sick bed so that they could consult with him. Neither May nor James were politically active, although like many in the Civil Service, learned Irish. One can sense their shifting sympathies in the letters.
The letter mainly concerns arrangements for May's impending visit and references to local gossip.

text.body:
27 Jan, 1916.
My darling girl,
This is going to be a very short
note indeed. Glad to see from your letter today
that mumps are better and that we may
really hope to see you both on Saturday. If
you are coming by first train let me know
as I should like to meet you at station
shall be on tenderhooks until then. By the
way wasn't a bit hurt over Miss Gertie Kelly's
remarks about the dancers. I suppose you'll
see the marriage in Dublin next week if you
care to turn up at Church. Where is it to be
and is Father McNamee going to pull the bolt.
If they're looking for a cheap job they ought to go
to the Registry Office as John threatened he would.
Remember me to your mother and Mrs S. Your loving little man
James
If USED FOR TRANSMISSION TO ANY PLACE ABROAD TO WHICH THE 1d. RATE
OF LETTER POSTAGE DOES NOT APPLY, THE ADDITIONAL POSTAGE REQUIRED
SHOULD BE PREPARED BY MEANS OF ADHESIVE POSTAGE STAMPS.
Miss Fay Togherstown
Ballina
Mullingar
